tassel.description: The tassel is the male inflorescence of maize, responsible for pollen production. Its development is controlled by multiple genes that regulate meristem identity, branching patterns, and floral organ formation. Compact tassels with reduced branching are preferred for high-density planting as they reduce shading and improve light penetration.

genes.name: Tassels replace upper ears 1
genes.function: Regulates suppression of axillary branch growth. Loss of TRU1 function causes upper ear positions to transform into long male-branch-like structures tipped by tassels.
mutations: tru1-ws: Loss-of-function mutation causing homeotic transformation of ears to tassel-like branches
genes.research: TRU1 encodes a BTB/POZ ankyrin domain protein. TB1 directly activates TRU1 by binding to motifs in its regulatory region. The tb1-tru1 pathway contributes to suppressing upper ear elongation and converting tassel-like branches into female ears during maize domestication.

genes.name: Tasselseed 4
genes.function: Controls sex determination in the tassel. Encodes microRNA172 which targets APETALA2-like transcription factors to prevent development of female flowers in the tassel.
mutations: ts4-1: Loss-of-function mutation causing development of female flowers in tassel
ts4-2: Partial loss-of-function with intermediate phenotype
genes.research: TS4 encodes microRNA172 (miR172), which targets the APETALA2-like transcription factor indeterminate spikelet1 (ids1/ts6). It functions to maintain male identity in the tassel by repressing genes required for carpel development.

genes.name: Barren inflorescence 2
genes.function: Regulates inflorescence branching and meristem maintenance. Required for proper tassel branch initiation and development. Encodes a serine/threonine protein kinase co-orthologous to Arabidopsis PINOID.
mutations: bif2-1: Null mutation causing severe reduction in tassel branching
bif2-77: Mu transposon insertion allele
bif2-RM: Reference mutant allele
genes.research: BIF2 encodes a serine/threonine protein kinase that phosphorylates ZmPIN1a (auxin efflux carrier) and BA1 (BARREN STALK1 transcription factor). Mutations result in reduced tassel branching, fewer spikelets and florets, and barren inflorescences.

genes.name: Indeterminate gametophyte 1
genes.function: Controls gametophyte development and leaf polarity. Encodes a LOB domain transcription factor similar to Arabidopsis ASYMMETRIC LEAVES2.
genes.pathway: Gametophyte development and leaf polarity pathway
mutations: ig1-mum: Mu insertion in first intron causing indeterminate gametophyte growth
ig1-O: Hopscotch retrotransposon insertion within coding region
genes.research: IG1 encodes a Lateral Organ Boundaries (LOB) domain protein. Loss-of-function mutants show prolonged free-nuclear divisions in embryo sacs, producing extra egg cells and polar nuclei. In leaves, ig1 mutants show disrupted adaxial-abaxial polarity and ectopic knox gene expression.

genes.name: Tasselseed 6 / Indeterminate spikelet 1
genes.function: Regulates sex determination and spikelet meristem determinacy. Encodes an APETALA2-like transcription factor targeted by ts4/miR172.
mutations: ts6-1: Null mutation with feminized tassel phenotype
ids1: Allele affecting spikelet determinacy
genes.research: TS6/IDS1 encodes an APETALA2-like floral homeotic transcription factor. It is the target of ts4/miR172. Mutations cause indeterminate spikelets, increased floral branching, and allow carpel development in tassels.

genes.name: Ramosa 1
genes.function: Controls tassel branch number and architecture. Encodes a C2H2 zinc-finger transcription factor with an EAR repression motif that imposes short-branch identity.
mutations: ra1-1: Loss-of-function causing increased tassel branching
ra1-R: Reference allele with normal branching
genes.research: RA1 encodes a C2H2 zinc-finger transcription factor expressed in a boundary domain near the base of spikelet-pair meristems. Loss of ra1 function causes increased long-branching in both tassels and ears. The gene underwent selection during maize domestication.

leafAngle.description: Leaf angle is the angle between the leaf blade and the stem. This trait is crucial for optimizing light capture, reducing mutual shading, and improving canopy photosynthesis efficiency. Modern maize breeding has selected for more upright leaves (narrow leaf angle) to increase planting density. Upright leaves allow more plants per hectare without yield penalty.

genes.name: Liguleless 1
genes.function: Controls ligule and auricle development, which directly affects leaf angle. The ligule is a structure at the junction of leaf blade and sheath that influences leaf positioning.
mutations: lg1-1: Complete loss of ligule and auricle, resulting in upright leaves
lg1-m1: Ac transposon-tagged allele
Lg1-R: Reference allele with normal ligule development
genes.research: LG1 encodes a SQUAMOSA promoter-binding protein (SBP) transcription factor. The LG1 protein localizes exclusively to the nucleus and functions cell-autonomously in the adaxial epidermis to instruct ligule formation. Mutations in LG1 result in the absence of ligules and auricles, causing leaves to grow more upright.

genes.name: Liguleless 2
genes.function: Works in conjunction with LG1 to regulate ligule development and leaf angle. Specifies the boundary region between leaf blade and sheath.
mutations: lg2-1: Loss-of-function mutation affecting ligule development
lg2-2: Null allele with enhanced upright leaf phenotype when combined with lg1
genes.research: LG2 encodes a basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor of 531 amino acids. It is crucial for specifying the boundary region between leaf blade and sheath, including correct development of ligule and auricles. Mutants also have defects in the transition from vegetative to reproductive development.

genes.name: ZmCLA4
genes.function: Regulates leaf angle through gravitropic response. Controls the asymmetric growth of the leaf base that determines leaf angle. Orthologous to LAZY1 in rice and Arabidopsis.
mutations: D132 allele: Lower expression associated with wider leaf angle
D132-NIL allele: Higher expression associated with narrower (more erect) leaf angle
genes.research: ZmCLA4 is a transcriptional repressor that negatively regulates leaf angle. Higher transcript levels correlate with narrower (more erect) angles. It affects cell shape and number at the junction of leaf and stem, and modulates gravitropic response. The protein contains a transmembrane domain and nuclear localization signal.

references.text: Ku et al. (2011) Journal of Experimental Botany 65: 5063-5076

genes.name: ZmILI1
genes.function: Controls leaf angle by regulating cell elongation in the leaf base. Encodes a basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor that modulates brassinosteroid biosynthesis.
mutations: zmili1-KO: CRISPR/Cas9 knockout showing reduced leaf angle (more erect leaves)
genes.research: ZmILI1 encodes a basic helix-loop-helix leucine zipper family transcription factor (HLH domain only, lacking basic DNA-binding region). It directly activates LG1 expression and represses CYP90D1 (brassinosteroid biosynthesis gene). Knockout mutants show reduced leaf angle, confirming its role in leaf architecture.

genes.name: ZmRAVL1
genes.function: Regulates leaf angle by controlling brassinosteroid biosynthesis. Encodes a B3-domain-containing transcription factor (ABI3-VP1 family) that modulates leaf architecture.
mutations: UPA2 variant: Cis-regulatory element affecting ZmRAVL1 expression
ZmRAVL1: Reference allele
genes.research: ZmRAVL1 activates brd1 (brassinosteroid C-6 oxidase1/UPA1) to alter endogenous BR content and influence leaf angle. The UPA2 locus (9.5 kb upstream) modulates ZmRAVL1 expression by affecting DRL1 binding, which interacts with LG1. The UPA2-ZmRAVL1-UPA1 pathway fine-tunes BR levels and leaf angle. The allele reducing leaf angle originated from teosinte.

references.text: Li et al. (2020) Journal of Experimental Botany 72: 1782-1795

genes.name: ZmLA1 (Lazy plant 1)
genes.function: Regulates shoot gravitropism and leaf/tiller angle. Controls the orientation of shoots and leaves relative to gravity through polar auxin transport.
mutations: la1: Loss-of-function causing prostrate stem phenotype
ps1 (prostrate stem1): Allelic to la1
genes.research: ZmLA1 is the maize ortholog of LAZY1 genes in rice and Arabidopsis. It regulates polar auxin transport (PAT): represses basipetal PAT in certain tissues but promotes lateral auxin movement in response to gravity. Mutants show severely reduced shoot gravitropism and defects in reproductive structures including smaller, disorganized ears and tassels.

stemHeight.description: Plant height is a critical agronomic trait controlled by multiple genes and environmental factors. Height affects lodging resistance, planting density, and yield. Dwarfing genes have been important in modern maize breeding to reduce lodging and allow higher planting densities. Semi-dwarf varieties are essential for high-density planting systems.

genes.name: Dwarf 1
genes.function: Encodes gibberellin 3-oxidase (ZmGA3ox2), catalyzing the final step in gibberellin biosynthesis to produce bioactive GAs (GA1, GA3, GA4).
mutations: d1-1: Severe dwarfing mutation with reduced gibberellin levels
d1-2: Moderate dwarfing allele causing andromonoecy
genes.research: D1 encodes gibberellin 3-oxidase, which catalyzes the conversion of GA20 to active GA1, GA5 to GA3, etc. The D1 protein is dual-localized to both the nucleus and cytosol. d1 mutants are severely dwarfed and show andromonoecy (male characteristics in female flowers).

references.text: Spray et al. (1996) Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 93: 10515-10518

genes.name: Dwarf 3
genes.function: Encodes a cytochrome P450 enzyme involved in an early step of gibberellin biosynthesis.
mutations: d3-1: Dwarfing mutation affecting GA biosynthesis
d3-2::Mu8: Mu transposon insertion allele
d3-4: Additional characterized allele
genes.research: D3 encodes a cytochrome P450 enzyme that participates in an early step of the gibberellin biosynthesis pathway. The D3 transcript is expressed in roots, developing leaves, the vegetative meristem, and suspension culture cells. Mutations cause dwarfism due to disrupted GA biosynthesis.

genes.name: Dwarf 8
genes.function: Negative regulator of gibberellin signaling. Encodes a DELLA protein that acts as a repressor degraded in the presence of gibberellin.
mutations: D8-1: Gain-of-function mutation with 4-amino-acid deletion plus substitution in DELLA motif causing severe dwarfism
D8-Mpl: Lacks entire N-terminal region
D8-1023: Insertion mutation in VHYNP motif
genes.research: D8 encodes a DELLA protein, a nuclear-localized negative regulator in the gibberellin signaling pathway. Gain-of-function mutations that disrupt DELLA motif result in dwarf plants insensitive to gibberellin because the mutant protein resists GA-mediated degradation.

genes.name: Brachytic 2
genes.function: Encodes ZmABCB1, an ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter (P-glycoprotein) involved in polar auxin transport affecting plant height.
mutations: br2-1: Loss-of-function mutation causing shortened lower stalk internodes
br2-2: Null allele with compact stalk phenotype
genes.research: BR2 encodes an MDR/P-glycoprotein (ZmABCB1) that mediates polar auxin transport. Mutations result in compact lower stalk internodes while upper parts remain nearly normal. The transporter affects auxin export especially from intercalary meristems in grass stalk nodes.

references.text: Kn√∂ller et al. (2010) Journal of Experimental Botany 61: 3689-3696

genes.name: Anther ear 1
genes.function: Encodes ent-kaurene synthase/cyclase, catalyzing the first committed step in gibberellin biosynthesis (conversion of GGDP to ent-kaurene).
mutations: an1-1: Loss-of-function causing dwarfism and perfect flowers on ears
an1-2: Additional characterized allele
genes.research: AN1 encodes ent-kaurene synthase, the enzyme catalyzing the conversion of geranylgeranyl diphosphate to ent-kaurene, the first step in the tetracyclic diterpenoid pathway of GA biosynthesis. an1 mutants show reduced plant height, delayed maturity, and development of perfect flowers (both male and female parts) on normally pistillate ears.

genes.name: ZmGA20ox3
genes.function: Encodes gibberellin 20-oxidase, a key enzyme in gibberellin biosynthesis. Controls the production of GA20 precursor for active gibberellins.
mutations: zmga20ox3-1: Loss-of-function with reduced height
zmga20ox3-OE: Overexpression line with increased height
genes.research: ZmGA20ox3 catalyzes the conversion of GA12 to GA20, a critical step in gibberellin biosynthesis. This is one of several GA20ox family members in maize (including ZmGA20ox4 and ZmGA20ox5). Overexpression increases plant height, while suppression reduces height.

genes.name: Dwarf 9
genes.function: Encodes a DELLA domain protein, a negative regulator of gibberellin signaling. One of two DELLA proteins in maize (along with D8).
mutations: D9-1: Dominant semi-dwarf mutation with E600K substitution in C-terminal region
genes.research: D9 is one of two DELLA-domain proteins in maize (the other is D8). These proteins act as negative regulators of gibberellin signaling. The D9-1 allele carries a C-terminal E600K substitution that confers the dominant semi-dwarf phenotype by making the protein resistant to GA-mediated degradation.

genes.name: Brassinosteroid-deficient dwarf 1
genes.function: Encodes brassinosteroid C-6 oxidase, catalyzing the final step in brassinosteroid biosynthesis. Also known as UPA1 (Upright Plant Architecture 1).
mutations: brd1-m1: Mu insertion causing extreme dwarfism and internode elongation defects
genes.research: BRD1 encodes a brassinosteroid C-6 oxidase participating in the final step of BR biosynthesis. Mutants (brd1-m1) have extreme dwarfism and internode elongation defects, which can be partially rescued by exogenous brassinolide. BRD1/UPA1 is activated by ZmRAVL1 in the leaf angle regulatory pathway.
